articles.headline: Some Suggestions for the New Consumer Chief
articles.snippet: Tasks that Elizabeth Warren might grapple with as the leader of the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.
articles.abstract: Tasks that Elizabeth Warren might grapple with as the leader of the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.
articles.lead_paragraph: So she got the job. What should she do with it?

articles.headline: Afghan Votes Come Cheap, and Often in Bulk
articles.snippet: In the elections for Parliament, a variety of tactics are used by some candidates to purchase support.
articles.abstract: In the elections for Parliament, a variety of tactics are used by some candidates to purchase support.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  How much does it cost to buy an Afghan vote?

articles.headline: The Illusion of Pension Savings
articles.snippet: A pension accounting technique that Illinois can use to help balance its budget is also being used in other states, but the maneuver may endanger the pension funds.
articles.abstract: A pension accounting technique that Illinois can use to help balance its budget is also being used in other states, but the maneuver may endanger the pension funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Illinois said it had found a way to save billions of dollars. It would slash the pensions of workers it had not yet hired. The real-world savings would not materialize for decades, of course, but thanks to an actuarial trick, the state could start counting the savings this year and use it to help balance its budget.

articles.headline: Spoiler Alert: Whodunit? Wikipedia Will Tell You
articles.snippet: It is getting harder to preserve surprise in entertainment from Web sites that offer endings of movies and plays.
articles.abstract: It is getting harder to preserve surprise in entertainment from Web sites that offer endings of movies and plays.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the end of each performance of the Agatha Christie play “The Mousetrap,” the person revealed to be the murderer steps forward and tells the audience to “keep the secret of whodunit locked in your heart.”

articles.headline: Chinese Investors Flock to London to Buy Real Estate
articles.snippet: Investors from mainland China and Hong Kong are more active than ever in the London real estate market.
articles.abstract: Investors from mainland China and Hong Kong are more active than ever in the London real estate market.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Naomi Minegishi, 21, a Japanese woman who lived in China for 10 years, recently took a job with the London property broker Felicity J Lord.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and Bettina Wassener

articles.headline: In Skyscraper at Ground Zero, Sentiment Trumped Numbers
articles.snippet: Few people seem willing to question whether building 1 World Trade Center makes any sense.
articles.abstract: Few people seem willing to question whether building 1 World Trade Center makes any sense.
articles.lead_paragraph: Timing is everything.

articles.headline: Tax Increase Would Hit Few Small Businesses
articles.snippet: More than 95 percent of businesses owners do not earn enough to be subject to the higher rates, and many of the businesses that would be affected have no employees.
articles.abstract: More than 95 percent of businesses owners do not earn enough to be subject to the higher rates, and many of the businesses that would be affected have no employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Congress and President Obama wrestle over whether to let the Bush tax cuts expire for the wealthiest Americans, one of the most heated aspects of the debate, in Washington and in neighborhoods across the country, is how a tax increase would affect small businesses.

articles.headline: Wide G.O.P. Field Tests the Waters for 2012 Contest
articles.snippet: The field is beginning to take shape in a period of upheaval set off by the rise of the Tea Party movement, presenting a complicated road to the nomination.
articles.abstract: The field is beginning to take shape in a period of upheaval set off by the rise of the Tea Party movement, presenting a complicated road to the nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES  The Republican presidential field for 2012 is beginning to take shape in a period of intensive upheaval set off by the rise of the Tea Party movement, expanding the roster of potential candidates but presenting a more complicated road to the nomination.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Drywall Flaws: Owners Gain Limited Relief
articles.snippet: Even as hundreds of lawsuits have been filed over tainted drywall, which was mostly made in China, most insurance companies have not paid a dime.
articles.abstract: Even as hundreds of lawsuits have been filed over tainted drywall, which was mostly made in China, most insurance companies have not paid a dime.
articles.lead_paragraph: Linda and Randall Hunter own their dream house in Plant City, Fla., with an oversize master bedroom, granite countertops in the kitchen and a screened-in pool.

articles.headline: Just Manic Enough: Seeking Perfect Entrepreneurs
articles.snippet: Though they may have many quirks, intense leaders are a common thread in the world of entrepreneurship.
articles.abstract: Though they may have many quirks, intense leaders are a common thread in the world of entrepreneurship.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cambridge, Mass.

articles.headline: When Mortgage Mediation Is a Gamble
articles.snippet: Nevada’s foreclosure mediation program completed 4,212 cases in its first year. But some mediators who have participated in it, as well as some lawyers for borrowers, say it has flaws.
articles.abstract: Nevada’s foreclosure mediation program completed 4,212 cases in its first year. But some mediators who have participated in it, as well as some lawyers for borrowers, say it has flaws.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEVADA — One of the states where home prices went stratospheric during the housing mania — is now reporting some of the nation’s most horrifying foreclosure figures. Last week, RealtyTrac said that 1 in every 84 households in the state had received a foreclosure notice in August, 4.5 times the national average.

articles.headline: Can Digg Find Its Way in the Crowd?
articles.snippet: A redesign is part of the Web site’s plan to regain momentum as it has lost ground in a crowded field that includes Facebook and Twitter.
articles.abstract: A redesign is part of the Web site’s plan to regain momentum as it has lost ground in a crowded field that includes Facebook and Twitter.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMY VERNON still recalls the first time, two years ago, when a story she posted on the social news site Digg became popular. She had promoted a blog post titled “Why Does Tony Almeida Hate America?” that riffed on the villain from “24,” the Fox television series. She watched it jump to Digg’s front page, leading to so many hits on her blog that her server crashed.

articles.headline: Missouri Tells Judges Cost of Sentences
articles.snippet: Judges in Missouri, in a hotly debated practice, are now told how much each type of sentence costs.
articles.abstract: Judges in Missouri, in a hotly debated practice, are now told how much each type of sentence costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS  When judges here sentence convicted criminals, a new and unusual variable is available for them to consider: what a given punishment will cost the State of Missouri.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Insider Fuels Tea Party and Suspicion
articles.snippet: In becoming one of the movement’s most successful players, the strategist Sal Russo is also fast becoming among the most divisive.
articles.abstract: In becoming one of the movement’s most successful players, the strategist Sal Russo is also fast becoming among the most divisive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In the days leading up to the Delaware primary, Sal Russo hosted a radio fund-raiser, organized a political rally and pressed the case with reporters that Christine O’Donnell was the Tea Party’s choice for the United States Senate. He also set off what he calls a “money bomb,” pouring at least $250,000 into television and other advertisements promoting the little-known candidate.
articles.byline: By Janie Lorber and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Wall Street’s Profit Engines Slow Down
articles.snippet: Inside the great investment houses on Wall Street, business has taken a surprising turn this summer — downward.
articles.abstract: Inside the great investment houses on Wall Street, business has taken a surprising turn this summer — downward.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside the great investment houses on Wall Street, business has taken a surprising turn — downward.

articles.headline: TV Guide Cuts Path to Relevance
articles.snippet: Sold two years ago for $1, the warhorse of TV listings is seeking a role in its market as it contends with the austerity of life under a private equity firm.
articles.abstract: Sold two years ago for $1, the warhorse of TV listings is seeking a role in its market as it contends with the austerity of life under a private equity firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was a time years ago when TV Guide’s fall television preview issues were hundreds of pages thick. Studios would clamor to get their ads placed next to the prime-time listings, knowing that the magazine sat on as many as 20 million coffee tables each week.

articles.headline: Japanese Playing a New Video Game: Catch-Up
articles.snippet: The West’s recent dominance in video games is spurring a growing group of Japanese game developers to ask a once-unthinkable question: can they learn from the West?
articles.abstract: The West’s recent dominance in video games is spurring a growing group of Japanese game developers to ask a once-unthinkable question: can they learn from the West?
articles.lead_paragraph: CHIBA, Japan  A supersonic hedgehog and a plumber named Mario may have been unlikely heroes, but they once dominated video games. Only the Japanese could make innovative games like those, developers here used to boast. The West just didn’t get it.

articles.headline: Arrest in Disputed Seas Riles China and Japan
articles.snippet: The Japanese Coast Guard’s arrest of a Chinese trawler captain in disputed waters has escalated into a diplomatic standoff.
articles.abstract: The Japanese Coast Guard’s arrest of a Chinese trawler captain in disputed waters has escalated into a diplomatic standoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  What started nearly two weeks ago with the Japanese Coast Guard’s arrest of a Chinese trawler captain in disputed waters has snowballed into a heated diplomatic standoff between China and Japan, highlighting anxieties in Asia about China’s rising power and assertiveness.
articles.byline: By Martin Fackler and Ian Johnson

articles.headline: Obama Aides Weigh Bid to Tie the G.O.P. to the Tea Party
articles.snippet: Political advisers are said to be considering a range of ideas, including national ads, to cast the Republican Party as all but taken over by extremists.
articles.abstract: Political advisers are said to be considering a range of ideas, including national ads, to cast the Republican Party as all but taken over by extremists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s political advisers, looking for ways to help Democrats and alter the course of the midterm elections in the final weeks, are considering a range of ideas, including national advertisements, to cast the Republican Party as all but taken over by Tea Party extremists, people involved in the discussion said.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Mormon-Owned Paper Stands With Immigrants
articles.snippet: A Utah paper’s sympathy for undocumented immigrants has led to a collision with its conservative readers.
articles.abstract: A Utah paper’s sympathy for undocumented immigrants has led to a collision with its conservative readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY  Joseph A. Cannon is nobody’s liberal. His résumé reads as if it belongs to a delegate to the Republican National Convention, which, incidentally, he was in 2004.

articles.headline: British Chip Designer Prepares for Wider Demand
articles.snippet: ARM, which designs low-power chips, commands a prime position amid one of the next technological revolutions.
articles.abstract: ARM, which designs low-power chips, commands a prime position amid one of the next technological revolutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England  Near the southeastern edge of Cambridge, where this idyllic university town gives way to fields of green, sits the headquarters of ARM Holdings. Neither the modest three-building campus nor its surroundings evoke notions of a thriving hotbed of computing.

articles.headline: Blurring Satire and Politics
articles.snippet: Media and entertainment figures like Glenn Beck and Jon Stewart are increasingly taking off the studio mikes and grabbing the political megaphones.
articles.abstract: Media and entertainment figures like Glenn Beck and Jon Stewart are increasingly taking off the studio mikes and grabbing the political megaphones.

articles.headline: Haitians Cry in Letters: ‘Please — Do Something!’
articles.snippet: Haitians displaced by the January earthquake have deposited impassioned pleas in suggestion boxes at camps.
articles.abstract: Haitians displaced by the January earthquake have deposited impassioned pleas in suggestion boxes at camps.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORAIL-CESSELESSE, Haiti  It was after midnight in a remote annex of this isolated tent camp on a windswept gravel plain. Marjorie Saint Hilaire’s three boys were fast asleep, but her mind was racing.

articles.headline: At Networks, Gloves Are Already Off
articles.snippet: In what has been described as the most intensely competitive opening night in recent memory, each of the four major networks has something to prove and a lot on the line Monday.
articles.abstract: In what has been described as the most intensely competitive opening night in recent memory, each of the four major networks has something to prove and a lot on the line Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The new TV season kicks off on Monday night  and it’s sure not starting with a whimper.

articles.headline: For the Unemployed Over 50, Fears of Never Working Again
articles.snippet: A growing number of those who desperately need to work fear they have already been shut out of the work force.
articles.abstract: A growing number of those who desperately need to work fear they have already been shut out of the work force.
articles.lead_paragraph: VASHON ISLAND, Wash.  Patricia Reid is not in her 70s, an age when many Americans continue to work. She is not even in her 60s. She is just 57.
